Markdown Content:
[![Image 1](

The [Parthenon]( "Parthenon"), a temple dedicated to [Athena]( "Athena"), located on the [Acropolis]( "Acropolis") in [Athens]( "Athens"), is one of the most representative symbols of the culture and sophistication of the ancient Greeks.

**Ancient Greece** ([Ancient Greek]( "Ancient Greek language"): Ἑλλάς, [romanized]( "Romanization of Ancient Greek"): _Hellás_) was a northeastern [Mediterranean]( "Mediterranean Sea") civilization, existing from the [Greek Dark Ages]( "Greek Dark Ages") of the 12th–9th centuries BC to the end of [classical antiquity]( "Classical antiquity") (c. 600 AD), that comprised a loose collection of culturally and linguistically related [city-states]( "Polis") and other territories. Prior to the [Roman period]( "Greece in the Roman era"), most of these regions were officially unified only once, when [Alexander the Great]( "Alexander the Great") incorporated them into his [Kingdom of Macedon]( "Kingdom of Macedon") for 16 years, from 338 to 323 BC.[\[a\]]( In [Western history]( "Western world"), the era of classical antiquity was immediately followed by the [Early Middle Ages]( "Early Middle Ages") and the [Byzantine]( "Byzantine Empire") period.[\[1\]](

Three centuries after the decline of [Mycenaean Greece]( "Mycenaean Greece") during the [Bronze Age Collapse]( "Late Bronze Age Collapse"), Greek urban [poleis]( "Poleis") began to form in the 8th century BC, ushering in the [Archaic period]( "Archaic Greece") and [the colonization]( "Greek colonisation") of [the Mediterranean Basin]( "Iron Age Greek migrations"). This was followed by the age of [Classical Greece]( "Classical Greece"), from the [Greco-Persian Wars]( "Greco-Persian Wars") to the death of [Alexander the Great]( "Alexander the Great") in 323 BC, and which included the [Golden Age of Athens]( "Golden Age of Athens") and the [Peloponnesian War]( "Peloponnesian War"). The unification of Greece by Macedon under [Philip II]( "Philip II of Macedon") and subsequent conquest of the [Achaemenid Empire]( "Achaemenid Empire") by Alexander the Great spread Hellenistic civilization across the Middle East. The [Hellenistic Period]( "Hellenistic Period") is considered to have ended in 30 BC, when the last Hellenistic kingdom, [Ptolemaic Egypt]( "Ptolemaic Egypt"), was annexed by the [Roman Republic]( "Roman Republic").

Classical [Greek culture]( "Culture of Greece"), especially philosophy, had a powerful influence on [ancient Rome]( "Ancient Rome"), which carried a version of it throughout the [Mediterranean]( "Mediterranean Basin") and much of Europe. For this reason, Classical Greece is generally considered the cradle of [Western civilization]( "Western culture"), the [seminal]( "wikt:seminal") culture from which the modern West derives many of its founding archetypes and ideas in politics, philosophy, science, and art.[\[2\]](

Chronology
----------

[Classical antiquity]( "Classical antiquity") in the Mediterranean region is commonly considered to have begun in the 8th century BC[\[5\]]( (around the time of the earliest recorded poetry of Homer) and ended in the 6th century AD.

Classical antiquity in Greece was preceded by the [Greek Dark Ages]( "Greek Dark Ages") (c. 1200 – c. 800 BC), [archaeologically]( "Archaeologically") characterised by the [protogeometric]( "Protogeometric art") and [geometric styles]( "Geometric art") of designs on pottery. Following the Dark Ages was the [Archaic Period]( "Archaic Greece"), beginning around the 8th century BC, which saw early developments in Greek culture and society leading to the [Classical Period]( "Classical Greece")[\[6\]]( from the Persian invasion of Greece in 480 BC until the death of Alexander the Great in 323 BC.[\[7\]]( The Classical Period is characterized by a "classical" style, i.e. one which was considered exemplary by later observers, most famously in the [Parthenon]( "Parthenon") of Athens. Politically, the Classical Period was dominated by [Athens]( "Classical Athens") and the [Delian League]( "Delian League") during the 5th century, but displaced by [Spartan hegemony]( "Spartan hegemony") during the early 4th century BC, before power shifted to [Thebes]( "Ancient Thebes (Boeotia)") and the [Boeotian League]( "Boeotian League") and finally to the [League of Corinth]( "League of Corinth") led by [Macedon]( "Macedon"). This period was shaped by the [Greco-Persian Wars]( "Greco-Persian Wars"), the [Peloponnesian War]( "Peloponnesian War"), and the [Rise of Macedon]( "Rise of Macedon").

Following the Classical period was the Hellenistic period (323–146 BC), during which Greek culture and power expanded into the [Near]( "Near East") and [Middle East]( "Middle East") from the death of Alexander until the Roman conquest. [Roman Greece]( "Roman Greece") is usually counted from the Roman victory over the [Corinthians]( "Corinth") at the [Battle of Corinth]( "Battle of Corinth (146 BC)") in 146 BC to the establishment of [Byzantium]( "Byzantium") by [Constantine]( "Constantine I") as the capital of the [Roman Empire]( "Roman Empire") in 330 AD. Finally, [Late Antiquity]( "Late Antiquity") refers to the period of [Christianization]( "Decline of Greco-Roman polytheism") during the later 4th to early 6th centuries AD, consummated by the closure of the [Academy of Athens]( "Plato's Academy") by [Justinian I]( "Justinian I") in 529.[\[8\]](

Historiography
--------------

The historical period of ancient Greece is unique in world history as the first period attested directly in comprehensive, narrative [historiography]( "Historiography"), while earlier ancient history or [protohistory]( "Protohistory") is known from much more fragmentary documents such as annals, king lists, and pragmatic [epigraphy]( "Epigraphy").

[Herodotus]( "Herodotus") is widely known as the "father of history": his _[Histories]( "Histories (Herodotus)")_ are eponymous of the entire [field]( "History"). Written between the 450s and 420s BC, Herodotus' work reaches about a century into the past, discussing 6th century BC historical figures such as [Darius I of Persia]( "Darius I of Persia"), [Cambyses II]( "Cambyses II") and [Psamtik III]( "Psamtik III"), and alluding to some 8th century BC persons such as [Candaules]( "Candaules"). The accuracy of Herodotus' works is debated.[\[9\]](

Herodotus was succeeded by authors such as [Thucydides]( "Thucydides"), [Xenophon]( "Xenophon"), [Demosthenes]( "Demosthenes"), [Plato]( "Plato") and [Aristotle]( "Aristotle"). Most were either Athenian or pro-Athenian, which is why far more is known about the history and politics of Athens than of many other cities. Their scope is further limited by a focus on political, military and diplomatic history, ignoring economic and social history.[\[14\]](

History
-------

### Archaic period

[![Image 2](

Dipylon Vase of the late [Geometric period]( "Geometric art"), or the beginning of the Archaic period, c. 750 BC.

The archaic period, lasting from approximately 800 to 500 BC, saw the culmination of political and social developments which had begun in the Greek dark age, with the _polis_ (city-state) becoming the most important unit of political organisation in Greece.[\[15\]]( The absence of powerful states in Greece after the collapse of Mycenaean power, and the geography of Greece, where many settlements were separated from their neighbours by mountainous terrain, encouraged the development of small independent city-states.[\[16\]]( Several Greek states saw tyrants rise to power in this period, most famously at [Corinth]( "Ancient Corinth") from 657 BC.[\[17\]]( The period also saw the founding of Greek colonies around the Mediterranean, with [Euboean]( "Euboea") settlements at [Al-Mina]( "Al-Mina") in the east as early as 800 BC, and [Ischia]( "Ischia") in the west by 775.[\[18\]]( Increasing contact with non-Greek peoples in this period, especially in the Near East, inspired developments in art and architecture, the adoption of coinage, and the development of the Greek alphabet.[\[19\]](

Athens developed its democratic system over the course of the archaic period. Already in the seventh century, the right of all citizen men to attend the [assembly]( "Ecclesia (ancient Greece)") appears to have been established.[\[20\]]( After a failed coup led by [Cylon of Athens]( "Cylon of Athens") around 636 BC, [Draco]( "Draco (lawgiver)") was appointed to establish a code of laws in 621. This failed to reduce the political tension between the poor and the elites, and in 594 [Solon]( "Solon") was given the authority to enact another set of reforms, which attempted to balance the power of the rich and the poor.[\[21\]]( In the middle of the sixth century, [Pisistratus]( "Pisistratus") established himself as a tyrant, and after his death in 527 his son [Hippias]( "Hippias") inherited his position; by the end of the sixth century he had been overthrown and [Cleisthenes]( "Cleisthenes") carried out further democratising reforms.[\[22\]](

In Sparta, a political system with two kings, a [council of elders]( "Gerousia"), and five [ephors]( "Ephors") developed over the course of the eighth and seventh century. According to Spartan tradition, this constitution was established by the legendary lawgiver [Lycurgus]( "Lycurgus (lawgiver)").[\[23\]]( Over the course of the [first]( "First Messenian War") and [second Messenian wars]( "Second Messenian war"), Sparta subjugated the neighbouring region of [Messenia]( "Messenia"), enserfing the population.[\[24\]](

In the sixth century, Greek city-states began to develop formal relationships with one another, where previously individual rulers had relied on personal relationships with the elites of other cities.[\[25\]]( Towards the end of the archaic period, Sparta began to build a series of alliances, the [Peloponnesian League]( "Peloponnesian League"), with cities including [Corinth]( "Corinth"), [Elis]( "Elis"), and [Megara]( "Megara"),[\[26\]]( isolating Messenia and reinforcing Sparta's position against [Argos]( "Argos, Peloponnese"), the other major power in the Peloponnese.[\[27\]]( Other alliances in the sixth century included those between Elis and [Heraea]( "Heraea (Arcadia)") in the Peloponnese; and between the Greek colony [Sybaris]( "Sybaris") in southern Italy, its allies, and the Serdaioi.[\[28\]](

### Classical Greece

[![Image 3](

Early [Athenian]( "Athens") coin, depicting the head of [Athena]( "Athena") on the obverse and her owl on the reverse – 5th century BC.

In 499 BC, the [Ionian]( "Ionia") city states under Persian rule rebelled against their Persian-supported tyrant rulers.[\[29\]]( Supported by troops sent from Athens and [Eretria]( "Eretria"), they advanced as far as [Sardis]( "Sardis") and burnt the city before being driven back by a Persian counterattack.[\[30\]]( The revolt continued until 494, when the rebelling Ionians were defeated.[\[30\]]( Darius did not forget that Athens had assisted the Ionian revolt, and in 490 he assembled an armada to retaliate.[\[31\]]( Though heavily outnumbered, the Athenians—supported by their [Plataean]( "Plataea") allies—defeated the Persian hordes at the [Battle of Marathon]( "Battle of Marathon"), and the Persian fleet turned tail.[\[32\]](

[![Image 4](

Map showing events of the first phases of the [Greco-Persian Wars]( "Greco-Persian Wars").

[![Image 5](

Delian League ("Athenian Empire"), immediately before the [Peloponnesian War]( "Peloponnesian War") in 431 BC.

Ten years later, a [second invasion]( "Second Persian invasion of Greece") was launched by Darius' son [Xerxes]( "Xerxes I").[\[33\]]( The city-states of northern and central Greece submitted to the Persian forces without resistance, but a coalition of 31 Greek city states, including Athens and Sparta, determined to resist the Persian invaders.[\[33\]]( At the same time, Greek Sicily was invaded by a Carthaginian force.[\[33\]]( In 480 BC, the first major battle of the invasion was fought at [Thermopylae]( "Battle of Thermopylae"), where a small rearguard of Greeks, led by three hundred Spartans, held a crucial pass guarding the heart of Greece for several days; at the same time [Gelon]( "Gelo"), tyrant of Syracuse, defeated the Carthaginian invasion at the [Battle of Himera]( "Battle of Himera (480 BC)").[\[34\]](

The Persians were decisively defeated at sea by a primarily Athenian naval force at the [Battle of Salamis]( "Battle of Salamis"), and on land in 479 BC at the [Battle of Plataea]( "Battle of Plataea").[\[35\]]( The alliance against Persia continued, initially led by the Spartan [Pausanias]( "Pausanias (general)") but from 477 by Athens,[\[36\]]( and by 460 Persia had been driven out of the Aegean.[\[37\]]( During this long campaign, the [Delian League]( "Delian League") gradually transformed from a defensive alliance of Greek states into an Athenian empire, as Athens' growing naval power intimidated the other league states.[\[38\]]( Athens ended its campaigns against Persia in 450, after a disastrous defeat in Egypt in 454, and the death of [Cimon]( "Cimon") in action against the Persians on Cyprus in 450.[\[39\]](

As the Athenian fight against the Persian empire waned, conflict grew between Athens and Sparta. Suspicious of the increasing Athenian power funded by the Delian League, Sparta offered aid to reluctant members of the League to rebel against Athenian domination. These tensions were exacerbated in 462 BC when Athens sent a force to aid Sparta in overcoming a [helot]( "Helot") revolt, but this aid was rejected by the Spartans.[\[40\]]( In the 450s, Athens took control of Boeotia, and won victories over [Aegina]( "Aegina") and Corinth.[\[39\]]( However, Athens failed to win a decisive victory, and in 447 lost Boeotia again.[\[39\]]( Athens and Sparta signed the [Thirty Years' Peace]( "Thirty Years' Peace") in the winter of 446/5, ending the conflict.[\[39\]](

Despite the treaty, Athenian relations with Sparta declined again in the 430s, and in 431 BC the [Peloponnesian War]( "Peloponnesian War") began.[\[41\]]( The [first phase of the war]( "Archidamian War") saw a series of fruitless annual invasions of Attica by Sparta, while Athens successfully fought the Corinthian empire in northwest Greece and defended its own empire, despite a [plague]( "Plague of Athens") which killed the leading Athenian statesman [Pericles]( "Pericles").[\[42\]]( The war turned after Athenian victories led by [Cleon]( "Cleon") at [Pylos]( "Battle of Pylos") and [Sphakteria]( "Battle of Sphacteria"),[\[42\]]( and Sparta sued for peace, but the Athenians rejected the proposal.[\[43\]]( The Athenian failure to regain control of Boeotia at [Delium]( "Battle of Delium") and [Brasidas]( "Brasidas")' successes in northern Greece in 424 improved Sparta's position after Sphakteria.[\[43\]]( After the deaths of Cleon and Brasidas, the strongest proponents of war on each side, [a peace treaty]( "Peace of Nikias") was negoitiated in 421 by the Athenian general [Nicias]( "Nicias").[\[44\]](

The peace did not last, however. In 418 BC allied forces of Athens and Argos were defeated by Sparta at [Mantinea]( "Battle of Mantinea (418 BC)").[\[45\]]( In 415 Athens launched an ambitious [naval expedition]( "Sicilian Expedition") to dominate Sicily;[\[46\]]( the expedition ended in disaster at the harbor of [Syracuse]( "Syracuse, Sicily"), with almost the entire army killed, and the ships destroyed.[\[47\]]( Soon after the Athenian defeat in Syracuse, Athens' Ionian allies began to rebel against the Delian league, while Persia began to once again involve itself in Greek affairs on the Spartan side.[\[48\]]( Initially the Athenian position continued relatively strong, with important victories at [Cyzicus]( "Battle of Cyzicus") in 410 and [Arginusae]( "Battle of Arginusae") in 406.[\[49\]]( However, in 405 the Spartan [Lysander]( "Lysander") defeated Athens in the [Battle of Aegospotami]( "Battle of Aegospotami"), and began to blockade Athens' harbour;[\[50\]]( driven by hunger, Athens sued for peace, agreeing to surrender their fleet and join the Spartan-led Peloponnesian League.[\[51\]]( Following the Athenian surrender, Sparta installed an oligarchic regime, the [Thirty Tyrants]( "Thirty Tyrants"), in Athens,[\[50\]]( one of a number of Spartan-backed oligarchies which rose to power after the Peloponnesian war.[\[52\]]( Spartan predominance did not last: after only a year, the Thirty had been overthrown.[\[53\]](

The first half of the fourth century saw the major Greek states attempt to dominate the mainland; none were successful, and their resulting weakness led to a power vacuum which would eventually be filled by Macedon under Philip II and then Alexander the Great.[\[54\]]( In the immediate aftermath of the Peloponnesian war, Sparta attempted to extend their own power, leading Argos, Athens, Corinth, and Thebes to join against them.[\[55\]]( Aiming to prevent any single Greek state gaining the dominance that would allow it to challenge Persia, the Persian king initially joined the alliance against Sparta, before imposing the [Peace of Antalcidas]( "Peace of Antalcidas") ("King's Peace") which restored Persia's control over the Anatolian Greeks.[\[56\]](

[![Image 6](

The _[Victorious Youth]( "Victorious Youth")_ (c. 310 BC) is a rare, water-preserved [bronze sculpture]( "Bronze sculpture") from ancient Greece.

By 371 BC, Thebes was in the ascendancy, defeating Sparta at the [Battle of Leuctra]( "Battle of Leuctra"), killing the Spartan king [Cleombrotus I]( "Cleombrotus I"), and invading Laconia. Further Theban successes against Sparta in 369 led to Messenia gaining independence; Sparta never recovered from the loss of Messenia's fertile land and the helot workforce it provided.[\[57\]]( The rising power of Thebes led Sparta and Athens to join forces; in 362 they were defeated by Thebes at the [Battle of Mantinea]( "Battle of Mantinea (362 BC)"). In the aftermath of Mantinea, none of the major Greek states were able to dominate. Though Thebes had won the battle, their general Epaminondas was killed, and they spent the following decades embroiled in wars with their neighbours; Athens, meanwhile, saw its second naval alliance, formed in 377, collapse in the mid-350s.[\[58\]](

The power vacuum in Greece after the Battle of Mantinea was filled by Macedon, under [Philip II]( "Philip II of Macedon"). In 338 BC, he defeated a Greek alliance at the [Battle of Chaeronea]( "Battle of Chaeronea (338 BC)"), and subsequently formed the [League of Corinth]( "League of Corinth"). Philip planned to lead the League to invade Persia, but was murdered in 336 BC. His son [Alexander the Great]( "Alexander the Great") was left to fulfil his father's ambitions.[\[59\]]( After campaigns against Macedon's western and northern enemies, and those Greek states that had broken from the League of Corinth following the death of Philip, Alexander began his campaign against Persia in 334 BC.[\[60\]]( He conquered Persia, defeating [Darius III]( "Darius III") at the [Battle of Issus]( "Battle of Issus") in 333 BC, and after the [Battle of Gaugamela]( "Battle of Gaugamela") in 331 BC proclaimed himself king of Asia.[\[61\]]( From 329 BC he led expeditions to Bactria and then India;[\[62\]]( further plans to invade Arabia and North Africa were halted by his death in 323 BC.[\[63\]](

### Hellenistic Greece

[![Image 7](

[Alexander Mosaic]( "Alexander Mosaic"), National Archaeological Museum, Naples.

The period from the death of Alexander the Great in 323 BC until the death of [Cleopatra]( "Cleopatra"), the last Macedonian ruler of Egypt, is known as the Hellenistic period. In the early part of this period, a new form of kingship developed based on Macedonian and Near Eastern traditions. The first Hellenistic kings were previously Alexander's generals, and took power in the period following his death, though they were not part of existing royal lineages and lacked historic claims to the territories they controlled.[\[64\]]( The most important of these rulers in the decades after Alexander's death were [Antigonus I]( "Antigonus I") and his son [Demetrius]( "Demetrius I of Macedon") in Macedonia and the rest of Greece, [Ptolemy]( "Ptolemy I Soter") in Egypt, and [Seleucus I]( "Seleucus I") in Syria and the former Persian empire;[\[65\]]( smaller Hellenistic kingdoms included the [Attalids]( "Attalid") in Anatolia and the [Greco-Bactrian kingdom]( "Greco-Bactrian kingdom").[\[66\]](

[![Image 8](

The major [Hellenistic]( "Hellenistic civilization") realms included the [Diadochi kingdoms]( "Diadochi"): Also shown on the map: The orange areas were often in dispute after 281 BC. The [Attalid dynasty]( "Attalid dynasty") occupied some of this area. Not shown: [Indo-Greek Kingdom]( "Indo-Greek Kingdom").

In the early part of the Hellenistic period, the exact borders of the Hellenistic kingdoms were not settled. Antigonus attempted to expand his territory by attacking the other successor kingdoms until they joined against him, and he was killed at the [Battle of Ipsus]( "Battle of Ipsus") in 301 BC.[\[67\]]( His son Demetrius spent many years in Seleucid captivity, and his son, [Antigonus II]( "Antigonus II"), only reclaimed the Macedonian throne around 276.[\[67\]]( Meanwhile, the Seleucid kingdom gave up territory in the east to the Indian king [Chandragupta Maurya]( "Chandragupta Maurya") in exchange for war elephants, and later lost large parts of Persia to the [Parthian Empire]( "Parthian Empire").[\[67\]]( By the mid-third century, the kingdoms of Alexander's successors was mostly stable, though there continued to be disputes over border areas.[\[66\]](

The great capitals of Hellenistic culture were [Alexandria]( "Alexandria") in the [Ptolemaic Kingdom]( "Ptolemaic Kingdom")[\[68\]]( and [Antioch]( "Antioch") in the [Seleucid Empire]( "Seleucid Empire").[\[70\]](

The conquests of Alexander had numerous consequences for the Greek city-states. It greatly widened the horizons of the Greeks and led to a steady emigration of the young and ambitious to the new Greek empires in the east.[\[72\]]( Many Greeks migrated to Alexandria, Antioch and the many other new Hellenistic cities founded in Alexander's wake, as far away as present-day [Afghanistan]( "Afghanistan") and [Pakistan]( "Pakistan"), where the [Greco-Bactrian Kingdom]( "Greco-Bactrian Kingdom") and the [Indo-Greek Kingdom]( "Indo-Greek Kingdom") survived until the end of the first century BC.

The city-states within Greece formed themselves into two leagues; the [Achaean League]( "Achaean League") (including Corinth and Argos)[\[73\]]( and the [Aetolian League]( "Aetolian League") (including Sparta and Athens).\[_[citation needed]( "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\] For much of the period until the Roman conquest, these leagues were at war, often participating in the conflicts between the [Diadochi]( "Diadochi") (the successor states to Alexander's empire).\[_[citation needed]( "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\]

The Antigonid Kingdom became involved in a war with the Roman Republic in the late 3rd century. Although the [First Macedonian War]( "First Macedonian War") was inconclusive, the Romans, in typical fashion, continued to fight Macedon until it was completely absorbed into the Roman Republic (by 149 BC). In the east, the unwieldy Seleucid Empire gradually disintegrated, although a rump survived until 64 BC, whilst the Ptolemaic Kingdom continued in Egypt until 30 BC when it too was conquered by the Romans. The Aetolian league grew wary of Roman involvement in Greece, and sided with the Seleucids in the [Roman–Seleucid War]( "Roman–Seleucid War"); when the Romans were victorious, the league was effectively absorbed into the Republic. Although the Achaean league outlasted both the Aetolian league and Macedon, it was also soon [defeated and absorbed by the Romans]( "Achaean War") in 146 BC, bringing Greek independence to an end.

### Roman Greece

The Greek peninsula came under Roman rule during the 146 BC conquest of [Greece]( "Greece") after the Battle of Corinth. [Macedonia]( "Macedonia (Roman province)") became a [Roman province]( "Roman province") while southern Greece came under the surveillance of Macedonia's [prefect]( "Prefect"); however, some Greek _poleis_ managed to maintain a partial independence and avoid taxation. The [Aegean Islands]( "Aegean Islands") were added to this territory in 133 BC. [Athens]( "Athens") and other Greek cities revolted in 88 BC, and the peninsula was crushed by the Roman general [Sulla]( "Lucius Cornelius Sulla"). The Roman civil wars devastated the land even further, until [Augustus]( "Caesar Augustus") organized the peninsula as the province of [Achaea]( "Achaea (province)") in 27 BC.

Greece was a key eastern province of the Roman Empire, as the [Roman culture]( "Roman culture") had long been in fact [Greco-Roman]( "Greco-Roman world"). The [Greek language]( "Koine Greek") served as a _[lingua franca]( "Lingua franca")_ in the East and in [Italy]( "Italia (Roman province)"), and many Greek intellectuals such as [Galen]( "Galen") would perform most of their work in [Rome]( "Rome").

Geography
---------

### Regions

[![Image 9](

Map showing the major regions of mainland ancient Greece and adjacent "barbarian" lands.

The territory of Greece is mountainous, and as a result, ancient Greece consisted of many smaller regions, each with its own dialect, cultural peculiarities, and identity. Regionalism and regional conflicts were prominent features of ancient Greece. Cities tended to be located in valleys between mountains, or on coastal plains, and dominated a certain area around them.

In the south lay the [Peloponnese]( "Peloponnese"), consisting of the regions of Laconia (southeast), Messenia (southwest), Elis (west), Achaia (north), Korinthia (northeast), Argolis (east), and Arcadia (center). These names survive to the present day as [regional units of modern Greece]( "Regional units of Greece"), though with somewhat different boundaries. Mainland Greece to the north, nowadays known as [Central Greece]( "Central Greece (geographic region)"), consisted of [Aetolia]( "Aetolia") and [Acarnania]( "Acarnania") in the west, [Locris]( "Locris"), [Doris]( "Doris (Greece)"), and [Phocis]( "Phocis (ancient region)") in the center, while in the east lay [Boeotia]( "Boeotia"), [Attica]( "Attica"), and [Megaris]( "Megaris"). Northeast lay [Thessaly]( "Thessaly"), while [Epirus]( "Epirus") lay to the northwest. Epirus stretched from the [Ambracian Gulf]( "Ambracian Gulf") in the south to the [Ceraunian Mountains]( "Ceraunian Mountains") and the [Aoos]( "Aoos") river in the north, and consisted of [Chaonia]( "Chaonia") (north), [Molossia]( "Molossia") (center), and Thesprotia (south). In the northeast corner was [Macedonia]( "Macedonia (ancient kingdom)"),[\[75\]]( originally consisting [Lower Macedonia]( "Lower Macedonia") and its regions, such as [Elimeia]( "Elimeia"), [Pieria]( "Pieria (regional unit)"), and [Orestis]( "Orestis (region)"). Around the time of [Alexander I of Macedon]( "Alexander I of Macedon"), the [Argead kings of Macedon]( "Argead dynasty") started to expand into [Upper Macedonia]( "Upper Macedonia"), lands inhabited by independent [Macedonian]( "Ancient macedonians") tribes like the [Lyncestae]( "Lynkestis"), [Orestae]( "Orestae") and the [Elimiotae]( "Elimiotis") and to the west, beyond the [Axius river]( "Axius river"), into [Eordaia]( "Eordaia"), [Bottiaea]( "Bottiaea"), [Mygdonia]( "Mygdonia"), and [Almopia]( "Almopia"), regions settled by Thracian tribes.[\[76\]]( To the north of Macedonia lay various non-Greek peoples such as the [Paeonians]( "Paeonians") due north, the [Thracians]( "Thracians") to the northeast, and the [Illyrians]( "Illyrians"), with whom the [Macedonians]( "Ancient Macedonians") were frequently in conflict, to the northwest. [Chalcidice]( "Chalcidice") was settled early on by southern Greek colonists and was considered part of the Greek world, while from the late 2nd millennium BC substantial Greek settlement also occurred on the eastern shores of the [Aegean]( "Aegean Sea"), in [Anatolia]( "Anatolia").

### Colonies

[![Image 10](

[Ancient Greek colonies]( "Greek colonisation") in the [archaic period]( "Archaic Greece").

[![Image 11](

The [Temple of Concordia]( "Temple of Concordia, Agrigento"), [Valle dei Templi]( "Valle dei Templi"), [Magna Graecia]( "Magna Graecia"), in present-day [Italy]( "Italy")

During the [Archaic period]( "Archaic Greece"), the Greek [population]( "Classical demography") grew beyond the capacity of the limited [arable land]( "Arable land") of Greece proper, [resulting in the large-scale establishment of colonies]( "Greek colonisation") elsewhere: according to one estimate, the population of the widening area of Greek settlement increased roughly tenfold from 800 BC to 400 BC, from 800,000 to as many as 7+1⁄2\-10 million.[\[77\]]( This was not simply for trade, but also to found settlements. These [Greek colonies]( "Greek colonies") were not, as Roman colonies were, dependent on their mother-city, but were independent city-states in their own right.[\[78\]](

Greeks settled outside of Greece in two distinct ways. The first was in permanent settlements founded by Greeks, which formed as independent poleis. The second form was in what historians refer to as _[emporia]( "Emporium (antiquity)")_; trading posts which were occupied by both Greeks and non-Greeks and which were primarily concerned with the manufacture and sale of goods. Examples of this latter type of settlement are found at [Al Mina]( "Al Mina") in the east and [Pithekoussai]( "Pithekoussai") in the west.[\[79\]]( From about 750 BC the Greeks began 250 years of expansion, settling colonies in all directions. To the east, the [Aegean]( "Aegean Sea") coast of [Asia Minor]( "Anatolia") was colonized first, followed by [Cyprus]( "Ancient history of Cyprus") and the coasts of [Thrace]( "Thrace"), the [Sea of Marmara]( "Sea of Marmara") and south coast of the [Black Sea]( "Black Sea").

Eventually, Greek colonization reached as far northeast as present-day [Ukraine]( "Ukraine") and Russia ([Taganrog]( "Taganrog")). To the west the coasts of [Illyria]( "Illyria"), [Southern Italy]( "Southern Italy") (called "[Magna Graecia]( "Magna Graecia")") were settled, followed by [Southern France]( "Southern France"), [Corsica]( "Corsica"), and even eastern [Spain]( "Spain"). Greek colonies were also founded in [Egypt]( "Ancient Egypt") and [Libya]( "Ancient Libya"). Modern [Syracuse]( "Syracuse, Italy"), [Naples]( "Naples"), [Marseille]( "Marseille") and [Istanbul]( "Istanbul") had their beginnings as the Greek colonies Syracusae (Συράκουσαι), Neapolis (Νεάπολις), Massalia (Μασσαλία) and [Byzantion]( "Byzantium") (Βυζάντιον). These colonies played an important role in the spread of Greek influence throughout Europe and also aided in the establishment of long-distance trading networks between the Greek city-states, boosting the [economy of ancient Greece]( "Economy of ancient Greece").

Politics and society
--------------------

### Political structure

[![Image 12](

Marble bust of Pericles with a [Corinthian helmet]( "Corinthian helmet"), Roman copy of a Greek original, [Museo Chiaramonti]( "Museo Chiaramonti"), Vatican Museums; Pericles was a key [populist]( "Populist") political figure in the development of the radical [Athenian democracy]( "Athenian democracy").[\[80\]](

Ancient Greece consisted of several hundred relatively independent [city-states]( "City-state") (_[poleis]( "Poleis")_). This was a situation unlike that in most other contemporary societies, which were either [tribal]( "Tribe") or [kingdoms]( "Realm") ruling over relatively large territories. Undoubtedly, the [geography of Greece]( "Geography of Greece")—divided and sub-divided by hills, mountains, and rivers—contributed to the fragmentary nature of ancient Greece. On the one hand, the ancient Greeks had no doubt that they were "one people"; they had the same [religion]( "State religion"), same basic culture, and same language. Furthermore, the Greeks were very aware of their tribal origins; Herodotus was able to extensively categorise the city-states by tribe. Yet, although these higher-level relationships existed, they seem to have rarely had a major role in Greek politics. The independence of the _poleis_ was fiercely defended; unification was something rarely contemplated by the ancient Greeks. Even when, during the second Persian invasion of Greece, a group of city-states allied themselves to defend Greece, the vast majority of _poleis_ remained neutral, and after the Persian defeat, the allies quickly returned to infighting.[\[81\]](

Thus, the major peculiarities of the ancient Greek political system were its fragmentary nature (and that this does not particularly seem to have tribal origin), and the particular focus on urban centers within otherwise tiny states. The peculiarities of the Greek system are further evidenced by the colonies that they set up throughout the Mediterranean, which, though they might count a certain Greek _polis_ as their 'mother' (and remain sympathetic to her), were completely independent of the founding city.

Inevitably smaller _poleis_ might be dominated by larger neighbors, but conquest or direct rule by another city-state appears to have been quite rare. Instead the _poleis_ grouped themselves into leagues, membership of which was in a constant state of flux. Later in the Classical period, the leagues would become fewer and larger, be dominated by one city (particularly Athens, Sparta and Thebes); and often _poleis_ would be compelled to join under threat of war (or as part of a peace treaty). Even after Philip II of Macedon "conquered" the heartlands of ancient Greece, he did not attempt to annex the territory or unify it into a new province, but compelled most of the _poleis_ to join his own [Corinthian League]( "Corinthian League").

### Government and law

[![Image 13](

Inheritance law, part of the [Law Code of Gortyn]( "Gortyn code"), Crete, fragment of the 11th column. Limestone, 5th century BC

Initially many Greek city-states seem to have been petty kingdoms; there was often a city official carrying some residual, ceremonial functions of the king (_[basileus]( "Basileus")_), e.g., the _[archon basileus]( "Archon basileus")_ in Athens.[\[82\]]( However, by the Archaic period and the first historical consciousness, most had already become aristocratic [oligarchies]( "Oligarchy"). It is unclear exactly how this change occurred. For instance, in Athens, the kingship had been reduced to a hereditary, lifelong chief magistracy (_[archon]( "Archon of Athens")_) by c. 1050 BC; by 753 BC this had become a decennial, elected archonship; and finally by 683 BC an annually elected archonship. Through each stage, more power would have been transferred to the aristocracy as a whole, and away from a single individual.

Inevitably, the domination of politics and concomitant aggregation of wealth by small groups of families was apt to cause social unrest in many _poleis_. In many cities a [tyrant]( "Tyrant") (not in the modern sense of repressive autocracies), would at some point seize control and govern according to their own will; often a populist agenda would help sustain them in power. In a system wracked with [class conflict]( "Class conflict"), government by a 'strongman' was often the best solution.

Athens fell under a tyranny in the second half of the 6th century BC. When this tyranny was ended, the Athenians founded [the world's first democracy]( "Athenian democracy") as a radical solution to prevent the aristocracy regaining power. A [citizens' assembly]( "Popular assembly") (the _[Ecclesia]( "Ecclesia (ancient Athens)")_), for the discussion of city policy, had existed since the reforms of [Draco]( "Draco (lawgiver)") in 621 BC; all citizens were permitted to attend after the reforms of [Solon]( "Solon") (early 6th century), but the poorest citizens could not address the assembly or run for office. With the establishment of the democracy, the assembly became the _[de jure]( "De jure")_ mechanism of government; all citizens had equal privileges in the assembly. However, non-citizens, such as [metics]( "Metic") (foreigners living in Athens) or [slaves]( "Slavery in ancient Greece"), had no political rights at all.

After the rise of democracy in Athens, other city-states founded democracies. However, many retained more traditional forms of government. As so often in other matters, Sparta was a notable exception to the rest of Greece, ruled through the whole period by not one, but two hereditary monarchs. This was a form of [diarchy]( "Diarchy"). The [Kings of Sparta]( "Kings of Sparta") belonged to the Agiads and the Eurypontids, descendants respectively of [Eurysthenes]( "Eurysthenes") and [Procles]( "Procles"). Both dynasties' founders were believed to be twin sons of [Aristodemus]( "Aristodemus"), a [Heraclid]( "Heracleidae") ruler. However, the powers of these kings were held in check by both a council of elders (the _[Gerousia]( "Gerousia")_) and magistrates specifically appointed to watch over the kings (the _[Ephors]( "Ephor")_).

Only free, land-owning, native-born men could be citizens entitled to the full protection of the law in a city-state. In most city-states, unlike the situation in [Rome]( "Ancient Rome"), social prominence did not allow special rights. Sometimes families controlled public religious functions, but this ordinarily did not give any extra power in the government. In Athens, the population was divided into four social classes based on wealth. People could change classes if they made more money. In Sparta, all male citizens were called _[homoioi]( "Homoioi")_, meaning "peers". However, Spartan kings, who served as the city-state's dual military and religious leaders, came from two families.[\[83\]](

#### Slavery

[![Image 14](

Gravestone of a woman with her slave child-attendant, c. 100 BC

Slaves had no power or status. Slaves had the right to have a family and own property, subject to their master's goodwill and permission, but they had no political rights. By 600 BC, [chattel slavery]( "Chattel slavery") had spread in Greece. By the 5th century BC, slaves made up one-third of the total population in some city-states. Between 40–80% of the population of [Classical Athens]( "Classical Athens") were slaves.[\[84\]]( Slaves outside of Sparta almost never revolted because they were made up of too many nationalities and were too scattered to organize. However, unlike later [Western culture]( "Western culture"), the ancient Greeks did not think in terms of [race]( "Race (human categorization)").[\[85\]](

Most families owned slaves as household servants and laborers, and even poor families might have owned a few slaves. Owners were not allowed to beat or kill their slaves. Owners often promised to free slaves in the future to encourage slaves to work hard. Unlike in Rome, [freedmen]( "Freedman") did not become citizens. Instead, they were mixed into the population of _[metics]( "Metic")_, which included people from foreign countries or other city-states who were officially allowed to live in the state.

City-states legally owned slaves. These public slaves had a larger measure of independence than slaves owned by families, living on their own and performing specialized tasks. In Athens, public slaves were trained to look out for [counterfeit coinage]( "Coin counterfeiting"), while temple slaves acted as servants of the temple's [deity]( "List of Greek mythological figures") and [Scythian]( "Scythians") slaves were employed in Athens as a police force corralling citizens to political functions.

Sparta had a special type of slaves called _[helots]( "Helots")_. Helots were [Messenians]( "Messenia (ancient region)") enslaved en masse during the [Messenian Wars]( "First Messenian War") by the state and assigned to families where they were forced to stay. Helots raised food and did household chores so that women could concentrate on raising strong children while men could devote their time to training as [hoplites]( "Hoplite"). Their masters treated them harshly, and helots [revolted]( "Slave rebellion") against their masters several times. In 370/69 BC, as a result of [Epaminondas]( "Epaminondas")' liberation of Messenia from Spartan rule, the helot system there came to an end and the helots won their freedom.[\[86\]]( However, it did continue to persist in Laconia until the 2nd century BC.

[Mosaic]( "Mosaic") from [Pompeii]( "Pompeii") depicting [Plato]( "Plato")'s [Academy]( "Platonic Academy")
